ranked_diseases.explanation: All three reference cases with similar phenotypes (unsteady gait and nystagmus) were diagnosed with this condition. The patient presents with the core neurological features seen in these cases.
Common autosomal dominant ataxia presenting with gait instability and nystagmus in adults. Age of onset typically in 30s-40s, matching patient's age.
Another common SCA with similar presentation of ataxia and nystagmus. Slightly less likely than SCA1 due to typical slower progression.
Most common SCA worldwide, presents with ataxia and nystagmus, though often has additional features not yet seen in this patient.
Pure cerebellar ataxia with nystagmus, typically later onset but can present in 30s. Milder progression than other SCAs.
Can present with unsteady gait and nystagmus due to cerebellar or brainstem lesions. Common in this age group but typically has relapsing-remitting course.
Classical hereditary ataxia with nystagmus, but typically presents before age 25. Late presentation possible but less likely.

ranked_diseases.disease_name: Cerebellar ataxia with neuropathy and vestibular areflexia syndrome (CANVAS)
ranked_diseases.explanation: Adult-onset ataxia with nystagmus, though typically includes sensory neuropathy and vestibular dysfunction not yet documented.
